facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 2093 and 2084 of 1970 were filed from the judgment and order dated January 28, 1964 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 104 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 2093 and 2084 of 1970. Appeals from the judgment and order dated January 28, 1964 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 104 of 1960.

facts.text: The assessee is a Limited Company.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee is a Limited Company and the matter relates to the assessment years 1956-57 and 1957-58, the companyresponding accounting years for which ended on June 30, 1955 and June 30, 1956 respectively.

facts.text: The matter relates to assessment years 1956-57 and 1957-58 with accounting years ending June 30, 1955 and June 30, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee is a Limited Company and the matter relates to the assessment years 1956-57 and 1957-58, the companyresponding accounting years for which ended on June 30, 1955 and June 30, 1956 respectively.

facts.text: Appellant Company was appointed as Managing Agent of Shree Ramesh Cotton Mills Ltd., Morvi by agreement dated 30-12-1946.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Company was appointed as the Managing Agent of Shree Ramesh Cotton Mills Ltd., Morvi  hereinafter referred to as the managed companypany , as per agreement dated 30-12- 1946.

facts.text: Shree Ramesh Cotton Mills Ltd., Morvi was a 100% subsidiary of the appellant company.

anchor.surface_text: The managed companypany was a 100 subsidiary of the appellant companypany.

facts.text: Under the agreement, appellant entitled to fixed office allowance of Rs. 1,000 per mensem plus commission at 12 1/2% of net profits, additional 1 1/2% on purchases of cotton and equal on sales of cloth and yarn.

anchor.surface_text: Under the terms of the agreement, the appellant companypany was entitled to receive a fixed office allowance of Rs. 1,000/- per mensem plus a companymission at the rate of 121/2 of the net profits, an additional companymission of 1 on all purchases of companyton and an equal amount on all sales of cloth and yarn.

facts.text: Managed company suffered losses in relevant years, profit commission nil, but commission on cotton purchases and sales aggregated Rs. 38,719 for 1956-57 and Rs. 1,963 for 1957-58.

anchor.surface_text: In the relevant years, the managed companypany suffered losses and companygruently the companymission payable at 121/2 of the net profits was nil but the companymission on purchase of companyton at the rate of 1 1/2 and on sales of cloth and yarn at the same rate, aggregated to Rs. 38,719/- for the assessment year 1956-57 and Rs. 1,963/- for the following year.

facts.text: Appellant entitled to Rs. 12,000 per annum fixed office allowance for each of the two years.

anchor.surface_text: Besides these amounts, the appellant was entitled to Rs. 12,000/- per annum for each of the two years as fixed office allowance.

facts.text: Total amounts appellant entitled to receive: Rs. 50,719 for 1956-57 and Rs. 13,963 for 1957-58.

anchor.surface_text: The total amounts which the appellant was entitled to receive from the managed companypany were Rs. 50,719/- and Rs. 13,963/- for the two years.

facts.text: Managed company's accounting year closed on 30th December, appellant's on 30th June every year.

anchor.surface_text: The managed companypanys accounting year closed on the 30th day of December and that of the appellant companypany on the 30th day of June every year.

facts.text: Clause 2(e) of Managing Agency Agreement dated 30th December 1946 provided commission due yearly on 31st December or other closing date, payable immediately after annual accounts passed by Board, Auditors and in General Meeting.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 2 e  of the Managing Agency Agreement dated 30th ember 1946 companytained the following term as to when the companymission would be due and payable The said companymission shall be due to the Agents yearly on the thirty-first day of December or any other date on which the Companys yearly account close in each and every year during the companytinuance of this Agreement and shall be payable and be paid immediate after annual accounts of the said Company has been passed by the Board of Directors and Auditors of the Company and by the companypany in, General Meeting.

facts.text: Annual General Meetings of managed company held on November 24, 1955 and July 21, 1956 to adopt accounts.

anchor.surface_text: The Annual General Meetings of the managed companypany were held to adopt the accounts on November, 24, 1955 and July 21, 1956 respectively with regard to the assessment years in question.

facts.text: Commission amounts due on 31st December 1954 and 31st December 1955, payable after November 24, 1955 and July 21, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The amounts of companymission in terms of the above clause were due on 31st December, 1954 and 31st December, 1955 and were payable immediately after the 24th of November, 1955 and 21st of July, 1956 respectively.

facts.text: Appellant relinquished managing agency commission for 1956-57 by Board resolution dated 4th April 1955 and for 1957-58 by resolution dated 19th June 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companypany relinquished the managing agency companymission for the assessment year 1956-57 as per resolution dated 4th of April, 1955 of the Board of Directors and for the following year as per resolution dated 19th June, 1956.

facts.text: Relinquishment occurred after amounts became due but before payable per clause 2(e).

anchor.surface_text: The amounts of the companymission were thus relinquished after they had become due but before they were payable in terms of clause 2 e  of the agreement.

facts.text: Managed company suffered heavy losses in past years.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant, it was stated that the managed companypany had been suffering heavy losses in the past years and, therefore, the appellant did number companysider it proper to charge any companymission or the fixed office, allowance and had companysequently relinquished the same.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer included Rs. 50,719 and Rs. 13,963 in appellant's total income for the two years.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer included the sums of Rs. 50,719/- and Rs. 13,963/- in the total income of the appellant for the two assessment years in question.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Income-tax Appellate Tribunal affirmed ITO's order.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner and the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal affirmed the order of the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Tribunal held commission became due on last day of managed company's accounting year, relinquishment after accrual inconsequential.

anchor.surface_text: According to the Tribunal, the companymission became due to the appellant yearly on the last day of the accounting year of the managed companypany, though the actual payment was deferred to a later date. Postponement of the actual payment after the income had accrued was held to be inconsequential. Likewise, the relinquishment of the income after it had become due in the opinion of the Tribunal, was inconsequential.

facts.text: Managed company's total loss carried over at end of 1955 was Rs. 14,95,221.

anchor.surface_text: it was observed that the total loss carried over at the end of year 1955 of the managed companypany was Rs. 14,95,221/-

facts.text: Tribunal referred two questions to High Court at instance of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the appellant, the Tribunal referred the following two questions to the High Court - Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the sums of Rs. 50,719/- and Rs. 13,963/foregone by the assessee by its Directors resolution dated 4- 4-1955 and 19-6-1956 respectively, were liable to be included in its total income for the accounting years ending 30-6-1955 and 30-6- 1956 ? If the answer to question No. 1 be in the affirmative, whether the assessee is entitled to claim an allowance of an equivalent amount as expenditure under the provisions of Section 10  2  xv  of the Indian Income Tax Act ?

facts.text: Calcutta High Court answered questions against assessee, in favour of respondent.

anchor.surface_text: This judgment would dispose of two Civil Appeal.s Nos. 2083 and 2084 of 1970 which have been filed on certificate granted by the Calcutta High Court and are directed against the Judgment of that Court whereby it answered the questions referred to the Court under Section 66 1  of the, Indian Income-tax Act, 1922  hereinafter referred to as the Act  for two assessment years against the assessee-appellant and in favour of the respondent.

facts.text: High Court held accrual complete within managed company's accounting year, relinquishment unilateral after due.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court agreed with the view taken by the Tribunal. It was observed that the accrual of income was companyplete within the accounting year of the managed companypany and as numberrelinquishment had been done before the amount became due, the case strictly came within the ambit of section 4  1   b  of the Act. numberrelinquishment, it was further observed, was a unilateral act of the appellant.

facts.text: Supreme Court finds commission accrued on 31 December 1954 and 1955, fixed allowance also entitled.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the first question is companycerned, we find that according to clause 2 e  of the Managing Agency Agreement reproduced above, the companymission for the two years in question became due to the appellant on the 31st day of December, 1954 and 31st day of December, 1955. The appellant also became entitled to receive fixed office allowance of Rs. 12,000/- for each of the two years.

facts.text: Appellant maintains accounts on mercantile system.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant-company admittedly was maintaining its account according to the mercantile system.

arguments.claim: Under s4(1)(b)(i), income includes what accrues; 'accrue' means becomes due; postponement affects payment not accrual; vested right arises.

anchor.surface_text: According to Section 4(1)(b)(i) of the Act, subject to the provisions of this Act, the total income of any previous year of any person includes all income, profits and gains from whatever source derived which if such person is resident in the taxable territories during such year accrue or arise

arguments.claim: Accrual distinct from receipt per s4(1)(a) vs (b); non-receipt post-accrual does not efface accrual.

anchor.surface_text: Clause (a) of sub-section (1) of Section 4 of the Act deals with the receipt of income while the, accrual of income is dealt with in clause (b) of that sub-section.

arguments.claim: Under mercantile system, income credited when legally due, even before receipt.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant-company admittedly was maintaining its account according to the mercantile system. It is well known that the mercantile system of accounting differs substantially from the cash system of book keeping.

arguments.claim: In Shoorji Vallabhdas, giving up commission before accrual is agreement for lesser remuneration, not here where unilateral after accrual.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay City I v. Messrs Shoorji Vallabhdas and Co. Hidayatullah, J as he then was speaking for the Court observed, Income-tax is a levy on income... Where, however, the income can be said not to have resulted at all, there is obviously neither accrual nor receipt of income

holdings.text: The commission for the two years in question became due to the appellant on the 31st day of December, 1954 and 31st day of December, 1955. The appellant also became entitled to receive fixed office allowance of Rs. 12,000/- for each of the two years. It, therefore, can be said that the income of Rs. 50,719/- had accrued to the appellant on 31st December, 1954 and of Rs. 13,973/- on 31st December, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the first question is concerned, we find that according to clause 2 e  of the Managing Agency Agreement reproduced above, the commission for the two years in question became due to the appellant on the 31st day of December, 1954 and 31st day of December, 1955. The appellant also became entitled to receive fixed office allowance of Rs. 12,000/- for each of the two years.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clause 2(e) of agreement fixes due date as 31 December annually; fixed allowance also entitled per terms.

holdings.text: The fact that the payment of the managing agency commission was deferred till after the accounts had been passed in the meetings of the managed company did not affect the accrual of the income of those amounts on December 31, 1954 and December 31, 1955 respectively.

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the pay- ment of the managing agency commission was deferred till after the accounts had been passed in the meetings of. the managed company did not affect the accrual of the income of those amounts on December 31, 1954 and December 31, 1955 respectively.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Postponement affects payment timing only, not accrual which occurs when due per contract.

holdings.text: According to Section 4(1)(b)(i) of the Act, the total income includes all income which accrue or arise; the income can thus be said to accrue when it becomes due; the postponement of the date of payment has a bearing only in so far as the time of payment is concerned, but it does not affect the accrual of income.

anchor.surface_text: According to Section 4  1   b   i  of the Act, subject to the provisions of this Act, the total income of any previous year of any person includes all income, profits and gains from whatever source derived which if such person is resident in the taxable territories during such year accrue or arise

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory definition and dictionary meaning of 'accrue' as 'become due'; vests right to claim upon accrual.

holdings.text: The further fact that the amount of income is not subsequently received by the assessee would also not detract from or efface the accrual of the income, although the non-receipt may, in appropriate cases, be a valid ground for claiming deductions.

anchor.surface_text: The moment the income accrues, the assessee gets vested with the right to claim that amount even though it may not be payable immediately. There also arises a corresponding liability of the other party from whom the income becomes due to pay that amount.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accrual distinct from receipt; unilateral waiver post-accrual does not erase vested right or liability.

holdings.text: Clause (a) of sub-section (1) of Section 4 of the Act deals with the receipt of income while the accrual of income is dealt with in clause (b) of that sub-section.

anchor.surface_text: Clause  a  of sub-section  1  of Section 4 of the Act deals with the receipt of income while the, accrual of income

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language distinguishes accrual basis from receipt basis.

holdings.text: The appellant-company admittedly was maintaining its account according to the mercantile system. Under the mercantile system credit entries are made in respect of amounts due immediately they become legally due and before they are actually received.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant-company admittedly was maintaining its account according to the mercantile system. It is well known that the mercantile system of accounting differs substantially from the cash system of book keeping.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessee follows mercantile accounting where income recorded on legal due date, not receipt.

holdings.text: In the present case, the amounts of income for the two years in question were given up unilaterally after they had accrued to the appellant company. As such, the appellant could not escape the tax liability for those amounts.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the amounts of income for the two years in question were given up unilaterally after they had accrued to the appellant company. As such, the appellant could not escape the tax liability for those amounts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unilateral post-accrual relinquishment ineffective to avoid tax; contrasts with pre-accrual agreement.

holdings.text: The relinquishment of the amounts should [not] be construed as permissible expenditure under section 10(2)(xv) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the second question, Mr. Maheshwari submits that the relinquishment of the amounts should be construed as permissible expenditure under section 10(2)(xv) of the Act. There is, in our opinion, no substance in any of the above contentions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No substance in contention; affirms High Court that not for commercial expediency or business purpose.

precedents.citation: Indermani Jatia V. Commis- sioner of Income-Tax, U.P.  1

anchor.surface_text: Indermani Jatia V. Commis- sioner of Income-Tax, U.P.  1

precedents.case_name: Indermani Jatia v. Commissioner of Income-Tax, U.P.
precedents.cited_proposition: Under the mercantile system of accounting, credit entries are made for amounts due when they become legally due even before actual receipt, and debits for liabilities incurred even before payment.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay City I v. Messrs Shoorji Vallabhdas and Co. 2

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay City I v. Messrs Shoorji Vallabhdas and Co. 2

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay City I v. Messrs Shoorji Vallabhdas and Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: Income-tax is levied on accrual or receipt of income; if income does not result, no tax even if booked; relinquishment after accrual/receipt does not prevent taxability, unlike cases where no accrual occurs due to agreement for lesser amount.
precedents.cited_holding: Giving up portion of managing agency commission was not relinquishment after accrual but agreement to receive lesser remuneration.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Maheshwari has assailed the findings of the High Court. Regarding the first question, the learned companynsel companytends that as the amounts in question were never received by the appellant but were relinquished, there arose numbertax liability for those amounts. As regards the second question, Mr. Maheshwari submits that the relinquishment of the amounts should be companystrued as permissible expenditure under section 10 2   xv  of the Act. There is, in our opinion, numbersubstance in any of the above companytentions. So far as the first question is companycerned, we find that according to clause 2 e  of the Managing Agency Agreement reproduced above, the companymission for the two years in question became due to the appellant on the 31st day of December, 1954 and 31st day of December, 1955. The appellant also became entitled to receive fixed office allowance of Rs. 12,000/- for each of the two years. It, therefore, can be said that the income of Rs. 50,719/- had accrued to the appellant on 31st December, 1954 and of Rs. 13,973/- on 31st December, 1955. The fact that the pay- ment of the managing agency companymission was deferred till after the accounts had been passed in the meetings of. the managed companypany did number affect the accrual of the income of those amounts on December 31, 1954 and December 31, 1955 respectively.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the first question is concerned, we find that according to clause 2 e  of the Managing Agency Agreement reproduced above, the commission for the two years in question became due to the appellant on the 31st day of December, 1954 and 31st day of December, 1955. The appellant also became entitled to receive fixed office allowance of Rs. 12,000/- for each of the two years.

Mr. Maheshwari has assailed the findings of the High Court. Regarding the first question, the learned companynsel companytends that as the amounts in question were never received by the appellant but were relinquished, there arose numbertax liability for those amounts. As regards the second question, Mr. Maheshwari submits that the relinquishment of the amounts should be companystrued as permissible expenditure under section 10 2   xv  of the Act. There is, in our opinion, numbersubstance in any of the above companytentions. So far as the first question is companycerned, we find that according to clause 2 e  of the Managing Agency Agreement reproduced above, the companymission for the two years in question became due to the appellant on the 31st day of December, 1954 and 31st day of December, 1955. The appellant also became entitled to receive fixed office allowance of Rs. 12,000/- for each of the two years. It, therefore, can be said that the income of Rs. 50,719/- had accrued to the appellant on 31st December, 1954 and of Rs. 13,973/- on 31st December, 1955. The fact that the pay- ment of the managing agency companymission was deferred till after the accounts had been passed in the meetings of. the managed companypany did number affect the accrual of the income of those amounts on December 31, 1954 and December 31, 1955 respectively.

anchor.surface_text: The moment the income accrues, the assessee gets vested with the right to claim that amount even though it may not be payable immediately. There also arises a corresponding liability of the other party from whom the income becomes due to pay that amount.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the amounts of income for the two years in question were given up unilaterally after they had accrued to the appellant company. As such, the appellant could not escape the tax liability for those amounts.

Mr. Maheshwari has assailed the findings of the High Court. Regarding the first question, the learned companynsel companytends that as the amounts in question were never received by the appellant but were relinquished, there arose numbertax liability for those amounts. As regards the second question, Mr. Maheshwari submits that the relinquishment of the amounts should be companystrued as permissible expenditure under section 10 2   xv  of the Act. There is, in our opinion, numbersubstance in any of the above companytentions. So far as the first question is companycerned, we find that according to clause 2 e  of the Managing Agency Agreement reproduced above, the companymission for the two years in question became due to the appellant on the 31st day of December, 1954 and 31st day of December, 1955. The appellant also became entitled to receive fixed office allowance of Rs. 12,000/- for each of the two years. It, therefore, can be said that the income of Rs. 50,719/- had accrued to the appellant on 31st December, 1954 and of Rs. 13,973/- on 31st December, 1955. The fact that the pay- ment of the managing agency companymission was deferred till after the accounts had been passed in the meetings of. the managed companypany did number affect the accrual of the income of those amounts on December 31, 1954 and December 31, 1955 respectively.

As regards the second question, Mr. Maheshwari submits that the relinquishment of the amounts should be construed as permissible expenditure under section 10(2)(xv) of the Act. There is, in our opinion, no substance in any of the above contentions.
